Project Number: 55241-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
 
 
Uzbekistan: Enhancing Private Sector Participation 
in Agriculture

Policy.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 10062021184151409648 Generated Date: 16-Jun-2021 13:22:58 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) for Enhancing Private Sector 
Participation in Agriculture will design support measures to increase private sector participation 
(PSP) in Uzbekistan’s agriculture sector. The TA will support (i) the preparation of a sector 
diagnostic study to evaluate the potential for PSP in the agriculture sector, with a focus on 
supporting  infrastructure,  including  irrigation;  (ii)  capacity-building  for  selected  government 
agencies, including the development of an awareness tool kit to help identify, appraise, implement, 
and manage PSP and public–private partnership (PPP) projects; and (iii) the preparation of the 
concept notes for two to three potential PSP and PPP projects, and other possible government 
support measures needed to boost PSP in the country’s agriculture sector. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country operations business 
plan for Uzbekistan, 2021–2023.1 Supporting private sector development is a priority area of 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan, 2019–2023.2 The TA will contribute to the 
achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 1, 2, and 10,3and is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
 
2030 operational priorities (OPs): OP1  on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, 
OP5 on promoting rural development and food security, and OP6 on strengthening governance 
and institutional capacity. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Agriculture sector production is vital to Uzbekistan’s food security, economic growth, and 
the livelihood of its people. In 2020, agriculture generated 28% of the country’s gross domestic 
product, provided employment to 27% of the labor force, and constituted 25% of the country’s 
merchandise exports.4 Out of 20.4 million hectares of agricultural land, 20.7% is irrigated. About 
85% of the irrigated land is cultivated by about 0.075 million large farms, while the remaining 15% 
is cultivated by about 4.9 million small farms and household plots.5 However, the sector’s gross 
output is below its full potential because of (i) inadequate irrigation, market, logistics, and road 
(farm to market) infrastructure; (ii) inefficient and fragmented value chains; and (iii) lack of support 
to farmers. 
 
4.  Much of the irrigation infrastructure in Uzbekistan is more than 30 years old and needs 
significant modernization. Low water user fees and poor recovery rates discourage investments 
to maintain existing irrigation infrastructure assets as well as new investments in future water 
development projects. The situation is expected to deteriorate with increasing aridity because of 
climate change and continued use of conventional irrigation techniques.6 
 
 
1  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Uzbekistan, 2021–2023. Manila. The TA first appeared in the 
business opportunities section of ADB’s website in October 2020.  
2  ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Uzbekistan, 2019–2023—Supporting Economic Transformation. Manila  
3  Goal 1-End poverty in all its forms everywhere; Goal 2- End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition 
and promote sustainable agriculture; Goal 6- Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation 
for all. 
4  State Statistics Committee of Uzbekistan. 2021. Social-economic Situation in the Republic of Uzbekistan, 2020. 
Tashkent. 
5  World Bank. 2020. Project Appraisal Document: Proposed Loan to the Republic of Uzbekistan for Agriculture 
Modernization Project. Washington, DC. 
6  FCG International. 2014. Climate Change and Sustainable Water Management in Central Asia. Central and West 
Asia Working Paper Series. No. 5. Manila: ADB

2 
5.  Uzbekistan’s infrastructure for logistics and wholesale and retail markets is insufficient and 
lacks strategic national coordination. The lack of all-weather rural roads hampers access to 
logistics hubs and implicitly results in price increases for agricultural products. 
 
6.  The agricultural value chain is characterized by weak linkages between value chain actors, 
as  well  as  insufficient  and  technologically  poor  logistics  and  storage  facilities  with  limited 
processing capacity. Public investments in agricultural research and development, extension 
services, and agribusiness development have been negligible. Private sector investments have 
been limited. Farmers have limited access to advanced agricultural technologies, productive 
seeds, effective fertilizers and pesticides, and appropriate financial resources and insurance 
products. 
 
7.  Considerable additional investments are required to address these issues and support the 
sustainable development of the agriculture sector in Uzbekistan, including increases in public 
budget allocations to the sector. 
 
8.  Provided with the right incentives, private sector investors and financiers can reduce the 
financing  gap  and  introduce  new  technologies  and  efficient  management  approaches.  The 
government recognizes that if it does not create an enabling environment for PSP, Uzbekistan 
will be unable to strategically maximize public investments to directly support the agriculture 
sector. 
 
9.  The government needs to develop a better understanding of how to engage private sector 
players for efficient service delivery. Prospective PSP and PPP projects need to originate from 
public  investment  planning  underpinned  by  a  medium-  to  long-term  sector  strategy.  The 
government needs to design and develop new projects that are sustainable from an engineering 
and environmental perspective, with more efficient operations and assets maintenance using PSP 
solutions,  including  strengthening  linkages  between  agricultural  inputs,  production,  storage, 
processing,  marketing,  and  capital  investment.  Appropriate  institutional  arrangements  and 
contractual frameworks must be designed and introduced to efficiently implement and manage 
contracts. Most importantly, the right incentives, regulatory framework, and budgetary support 
must be created so private investors, operators, farmers, public agencies, and other stakeholders 
can work together on mutually beneficial and sustainable schemes. 
 
10.  Increased PSP is expected to contribute to sustainable agriculture sector development. A 
comprehensive diagnostic study is needed to improve the understanding of the potential benefits 
and challenges of PSP and PPP projects in the agriculture sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: private sector development in the agriculture 
sector supported (footnote 2). The TA will have the following outcome: enabling environment for 
PSP and PPP in the agriculture sector strengthened.7 
 
 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Conditions for enabling PSP and PPP in the agriculture sector identified. 
Output 1 will help the government improve the legal and institutional framework for PSP and PPP 
projects in the agriculture sector. It will assess the environment, key constraints, opportunities, 
and capacity needs for PSP through a sector diagnostic study. This diagnostic study will be 
prepared in consultation with private sector stakeholders8 and development partners.9 It will 
assess the interest and perception of risk among private sector players—including investors and 
financiers—through market soundings10 to provide recommendations on key opportunities and 
interventions to improve the PSP enabling environment. The diagnostic study will also assess 
climate risks and adaptation actions in areas related to PSP development. 
 
13.  Output 2: Public sector specialists’ knowledge in PSP and PPP enhanced. Output 2 
will enhance the capacity of government agencies to identify, appraise, implement, and manage 
PSP and PPP projects in the agriculture sector. Based on the findings of the diagnostic study, the 
TA will (i) develop an awareness tool kit to identify, appraise, implement, and manage agricultural 
PSP and PPP projects, including evaluation of environmental, climate change, and social risks; 
and (ii) conduct tailor-made sector-specific trainings with case studies in various aspects of PSP 
and PPP for at least 60 staff of the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA), the Ministry of Water Resources 
(MWR), and provincial government authorities. Professionals from the private sector will be 
engaged as resource persons and trainers. 
 
14.  Output 3: Potential PSP and PPP projects identified. Output 3 will help the MOA and 
MWR identify feasible PSP and PPP agricultural projects for detailed appraisal and structuring. It 
will prepare the concept notes (prefeasibility studies) for two to three potential PSP and PPP 
projects, which will be approved by the MOA and MWR as a pipeline of bankable projects for 
detailed appraisal and structuring with ADB support. The potential areas for PSP and PPP 
development  include  (i)  agricultural  value  chains;  (ii)  agricultural  research,  innovation,  and 
technology transfer; (iii) building, upgrading, and operation of irrigation, market, logistics, and rural 
road infrastructure; and (iv) delivery of business development services to farmers and small 
enterprises or other financial support, insurance, or policy instruments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office space for TA 
consultants,  counterpart  staff,  data  and  information  access,  facilitation  of  liaisons  with 
stakeholders, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The Uzbekistan Resident Mission of ADB’s Central and West 
Asia Department will implement the TA in consultation with the Environment, Natural Resources 
 
8  Agribusiness firms, farmers, agricultural clusters, agricultural inputs suppliers, commercial banks, and wholesale and 
retail firms. 
9  The European Union, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, and the World Bank. 
10 Structured dialogues through meetings or written communication with private sector companies, investors, and 
financiers.

4 
and Agriculture Division; the Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division; and the 
Client Solutions Team of the department. The MOA will be the key counterpart government 
agency involved in TA implementation and will be responsible for coordination with the MWR and 
other  government  agencies.  Private  sector  institutions  will  be  closely  consulted  in  the 
implementation of the TA (footnote 10). The TA products consisting of (i) awareness tool kit to 
identify, appraise, implement, and manage agricultural PSP and PPP projects; and (ii) concept 
notes for potential PSP and PPP projects, will be prepared in close consultation with staff from 
ADB’s Office of Public-Private Partnership and the Private Sector Operations Department. 
 
18.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2021–December 2023 
Executing agency  ADB  
Implementing agencies  ADB’s Uzbekistan Resident Mission in consultation with CWER, 
CWPF, and Client Solutions Team 
Key counterpart government agencies: Ministry of Agriculture, and 
Ministry of Water Resources 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual: Individual  International expertise  $300,000 
selection  (14 person-months) 
Individual: Individual  National expertise (30  $90,000 
selection  person-months) 
Disbursement  Disbursement of technical assistance resources will follow ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended 
from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank; CWER = Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division; CWPF = Public 
Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.11 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Uzbekistan for Enhancing Private Sector Participation in Agriculture, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
11Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestone 
1.  Conditions for enabling PSP and PPP in the agriculture sector identified 
1.1 MOA and MWR appoint project focal points in December 2021. 
1.2 Review national legal, regulatory, and institutional PSP framework by Q1 2022. 
1.3 Conduct consultation meetings with the MOA, MWR, development partners, and private sector 
representatives by Q2 2022. 
1.4 Prepare the sector diagnostic study and capacity needs assessment report by Q2 2022. 
1.5 Conduct the workshop for the MOA, MWR, and local governments to present and discuss the findings 
of the sector diagnostic study by Q3 2022. 
2.  Public sector specialists’ knowledge in PSP and PPP enhanced 
2.1. Develop an awareness tool kit to identify, appraise, implement, and manage PSP and PPP projects 
by Q4 2022. 
2.2. Conduct PSP and PPP trainings by Q4 2022. 
3.  Potential PSP and PPP projects identified 
3.1. MOA and MWR submit the long list of potential PSPS and PPP projects by Q1 2022. 
3.2. Prepare the concept notes for two to three PSP and PPP projects by Q2 2023. 
TA Management Activities 
Recruit consultants by Q1 2022.
